name: 11th Karmapa
description: The eleventh recognized incarnation of the Karmapa lineage died at a young age

name: Orgyan Tendzin Norbu
description: Orgyan Tendzin Norbu was the chief disciple of Patrul Rinpoche
Associated Monasteries: [Orgyan Tendzin Norbu](tm.fig.25)|[Bodong E](tm.mon.62)|||,[Orgyan Tendzin Norbu](tm.fig.25)|[Kailash](tm.mon.79)|||

name: Sonam Tsemo
description: Sonam Tsemo was the fourth throne holder of Sakya monastery. He wrote works on Mahayana philosophy and tantra.
Associated Monasteries: [Sonam Tsemo](tm.fig.26)|[Sangpu](tm.mon.11)|||,[Sonam Tsemo](tm.fig.26)|[Sakya](tm.mon.13)|||

name: Lama Dampa Sonam Gyeltsen
description: Lama Dampa Sonam Gyeltsap was a scholar of Lamdre (the chief tantric system of Sakya), and author of a famous history of early Tibet. He was closely involved with many of the powerful political rulers of his day

name: Go Lotsawa Shonnu Pel
description: Go Lotsawa Shonnu Pel is most famous for writing the Blue Annals, a detailed history of Tibetan Buddhism and its lineages from the introduction of the religion into Tibet. Go Lotsawa also wrote extensive scholarly works on other subjects.
Associated Monasteries: [Go Lotsawa Shonnu Pel](tm.fig.28)|[Yangpachen](tm.mon.47)|||

name: 5th Panchen Lama, Lobzang Yeshe
description: The Fifth Panchen Lama was tutored and given vows by the Fifth Dalai Lama. He attempted to act as tutor to the Sixth Dalai Lama, but the latter renounced his vows and religious education. The Panchen Lama played a significant role in the politics of the late 17th and early 18th centuries.
Associated Monasteries: "[5th Panchen Lama, Lobzang Yeshe](tm.fig.29)|[Tashilhunpo](tm.mon.37)|||","[5th Panchen Lama, Lobzang Yeshe](tm.fig.29)|[Chakpori](tm.mon.14)|||","[5th Panchen Lama, Lobzang Yeshe](tm.fig.29)|[Potala](tm.mon.48)|||"

name: Puntsok Pelzang
description: Although Puntsok Pelzang's education was in Kagyu monasteries, he was one of the chief disciples of the Jonang master. He received and transmitted initiations of the Kalachakra, and other tantras, and defended Jonang philosophy in debates with Geluk monks.

name: Zhabkar Tsokdruk Rangdrol
description: Somewhat unusually for the Geluk tradition, Zhabkar Tsokdruk Rangdrol spent most of his religious career as a tantric practitioner, engaging in solitary retreats and instructing students individually. He went on pilgrimage all over Tibet and to Bodhanath, Nepal
Associated Monasteries: [Zhabkar Tsokdruk Rangdrol](tm.fig.31)|[Boudanath](tm.mon.50)|||,[Zhabkar Tsokdruk Rangdrol](tm.fig.31)|[Dobi Ganden Pelgye Ling](tm.mon.58)|||,[Zhabkar Tsokdruk Rangdrol](tm.fig.31)|[Kailash](tm.mon.79)|||

name: Sherab Sengge
description: Sherab Sengge was one of the disciples of Tsongkhapa. He received the transmission of the Guhyasamaja tantra and specialized in that practice. Sherab Sengge founded Lower Tantric College.

name: The First Dzogchen Drubwang, Pema Rigdzin
description: Pema Rigdzin was a revealer (Terton) and transmitter of treasure traditions, particularly in the Dzogchen tradition.
Associated Monasteries: "[The First Dzogchen Drubwang, Pema Rigdzin](tm.fig.33)|[Dorje Drak](tm.mon.4)|||","[The First Dzogchen Drubwang, Pema Rigdzin](tm.fig.33)|[Dzogchen](tm.mon.7)|||","[The First Dzogchen Drubwang, Pema Rigdzin](tm.fig.33)|[Pelyul](tm.mon.52)|||","[The First Dzogchen Drubwang, Pema Rigdzin](tm.fig.33)|[Sekhar Gutok](tm.mon.29)|||","[The First Dzogchen Drubwang, Pema Rigdzin](tm.fig.33)|[Sera Me](tm.mon.1)|||","[The First Dzogchen Drubwang, Pema Rigdzin](tm.fig.33)|[Drepung](tm.mon.5)|||","[The First Dzogchen Drubwang, Pema Rigdzin](tm.fig.33)|[Daklha Gampo](tm.mon.60)|||","[The First Dzogchen Drubwang, Pema Rigdzin](tm.fig.33)|[Taklung](tm.mon.49)|||","[The First Dzogchen Drubwang, Pema Rigdzin](tm.fig.33)|[Tsurphu](tm.mon.12)|||","[The First Dzogchen Drubwang, Pema Rigdzin](tm.fig.33)|[Samye](tm.mon.20)|||","[The First Dzogchen Drubwang, Pema Rigdzin](tm.fig.33)|[Chamdo Jampa Ling](tm.mon.75)|||","[The First Dzogchen Drubwang, Pema Rigdzin](tm.fig.33)|[Reting](tm.mon.40)|||","[The First Dzogchen Drubwang, Pema Rigdzin](tm.fig.33)|[Drak Yongdzong](tm.mon.90)|||"

name: Patrul Orgyen Jigme Chokyi Wangpo
description: Patrul Rinpoche was part of the Pelge incarnation lineage and also considered as an incarnation of Jigme Lingpa. He is most famous as the author of “Words of My Perfect Teacher”, based on his guru Jigme Gyelwai Nyugu’s oral instructions on the Longchen Nyinthig. In general Patrul Rinpoche gave many instructions aimed at the exoteric level or the novice practitioner.
Associated Monasteries: [Patrul Orgyen Jigme Chokyi Wangpo](tm.fig.34)|[Dzogchen](tm.mon.7)|||,[Patrul Orgyen Jigme Chokyi Wangpo](tm.fig.34)|[Palge Samten Ling](tm.mon.53)|||,[Patrul Orgyen Jigme Chokyi Wangpo](tm.fig.34)|[Dzagyel](tm.mon.61)|||

name: Chokyi Sengge
description: Chokyi Sengge was the abbot of Sangphu Netok and author of a number of philosophical works on Madhyamaka and epistemology.

name: Buton Rinchen Drup
description: Buton Rinchen Drup was the abbot of Zhalu monastery and established a curriculum for philosophy and tantra. He created one of the first collections of the Tibetan scriptural canon and commentaries. Buton also wrote a famous history of Buddhism.
Associated Monasteries: [Buton Rinchen Drup](tm.fig.36)|[Zhalu](tm.mon.54)|||,[Buton Rinchen Drup](tm.fig.36)|[Nartang](tm.mon.44)|||,[Buton Rinchen Drup](tm.fig.36)|[Tsel Gungtang](tm.mon.27)|||,[Buton Rinchen Drup](tm.fig.36)|[Sakya](tm.mon.13)|||

name: Vanaratna
description: Vanaratna was an Indian monk from Eastern Bengal who took several journeys to Tibet. He collected Vajrayana teachings from around India, as they existed in that period of Buddhism’s decline. Vanaratna translated Indian texts and transmitted the Kalachakra teachings and the six branch yoga practice.
Associated Monasteries: [Vanaratna](tm.fig.37)|[Densatil](tm.mon.55)|||,[Vanaratna](tm.fig.37)|[Ralung](tm.mon.57)|||,[Vanaratna](tm.fig.37)|[Pelkhor Chode](tm.mon.81)|||,[Vanaratna](tm.fig.37)|[Samye](tm.mon.20)|||,[Vanaratna](tm.fig.37)|[Sakya](tm.mon.13)|||,[Vanaratna](tm.fig.37)|[Lhasa Tsuklakhang](tm.mon.94)|||

name: Fifth Dalai Lama, Ngawang Lobzang Gyatso
description: The "Great Fifth" Dalai Lama was the first Dalai Lama to rule Tibet under the Ganden Phodrang regime, after obtaining hegemony over Tibet (aided by the Mongolian Gushri Khan) against Kagyu forces. While persecuting Jonang and Karma Kagyu, the Fifth Dalai Lama established a Geluk hegemony and also patronized and transmitted Nyingma teachings.
Associated Monasteries: "[Fifth Dalai Lama, Ngawang Lobzang Gyatso](tm.fig.38)|[Drepung](tm.mon.5)|||","[Fifth Dalai Lama, Ngawang Lobzang Gyatso](tm.fig.38)|[Arik Gonchen](tm.mon.56)|||","[Fifth Dalai Lama, Ngawang Lobzang Gyatso](tm.fig.38)|[Lhasa Tsuklakhang](tm.mon.94)|||","[Fifth Dalai Lama, Ngawang Lobzang Gyatso](tm.fig.38)|[Potala](tm.mon.48)|||"

name: Dolpopa Sherab Gyaltsen
description: Dolpopa was one of the key figures in the Jonang movement, and was best known for teaching the Kalachakra tantra, and developing the zhentong view of emptiness. This view was rejected by the Geluk school as heretical and persecuted. However, other traditions of Tibetan Buddhism accept it as a valid interpretation of emptiness.
Associated Monasteries: [Dolpopa Sherab Gyaltsen](tm.fig.39)|[Ralung](tm.mon.57)|||,[Dolpopa Sherab Gyaltsen](tm.fig.39)|[Jonang](tm.mon.10)|||,[Dolpopa Sherab Gyaltsen](tm.fig.39)|[Tsurphu](tm.mon.12)|||,[Dolpopa Sherab Gyaltsen](tm.fig.39)|[Nenying](tm.mon.76)|||,[Dolpopa Sherab Gyaltsen](tm.fig.39)|[Sakya](tm.mon.13)|||

name: 14th Karmapa Tekchok Dorje
description: Tekchok Dorje was the fourteenth incarnation of the Karmapa line and was chosen by the Golden Urn in the era when the Qing dynasty controlled the incarnation system.
Associated Monasteries: [14th Karmapa Tekchok Dorje](tm.fig.40)|[Karma Gon](tm.mon.36)|||,[14th Karmapa Tekchok Dorje](tm.fig.40)|[Tsurphu](tm.mon.12)|||

name: Pang Lotsawa Lodro Tenpa
description: Pang Lotsawa was best known for his knowledge of the Sanskrit language, much of which came from studies in Nepal. He also translated treatises into Tibetan and wrote commentaries on the Kalachakra.
Associated Monasteries: [Pang Lotsawa Lodro Tenpa](tm.fig.41)|[Samye](tm.mon.20)|||,[Pang Lotsawa Lodro Tenpa](tm.fig.41)|[Bodong E](tm.mon.62)|||

name: Arik Geshe Jampa Gelek Gyeltsen
description: Arik Geshe Jampa Gelek Gyeltsen was tutor to important Geluk figures including Ganden Tripas and Changkya incarnations. He founded the Ganden Tashi Jungne monastic college.
Associated Monasteries: [Arik Geshe Jampa Gelek Gyeltsen](tm.fig.42)|[Kumbum Jampa Ling](tm.mon.28)|||,[Arik Geshe Jampa Gelek Gyeltsen](tm.fig.42)|[Purbuchok](tm.mon.63)|||,[Arik Geshe Jampa Gelek Gyeltsen](tm.fig.42)|[Amdo Chubzang](tm.mon.71)|||

name: Khedrup Norzang Gyatso
description: Khedrup Norzang Gyatso was an expert in Lamrim (stages of the Buddhist path), tutor of the Second Dalai Lama, and scholar and practitioner of Guhyasamaja and other tantras.
Associated Monasteries: [Khedrup Norzang Gyatso](tm.fig.43)|[Ngor](tm.mon.23)|||,[Khedrup Norzang Gyatso](tm.fig.43)|[Sakya](tm.mon.13)|||

name: Nyima Drakpa
description: Nyima Drakpa received transmissions of the Bardo Thodol practices (liberation through hearing), and wrote down the practice in a form known in the West as the Tibetan Book of the Dead. Nyima Drakpa was known as a fighter of demons but these practices were controversial and led to accusations that he was practicing black magic. He has a close relationship with the Fifth and Sixth Dalai Lamas and the regent Desi Sanggye Gyatso. He founded Dzokchen monastery.
Associated Monasteries: [Nyima Drakpa](tm.fig.44)|[Mindroling](tm.mon.39)|||,[Nyima Drakpa](tm.fig.44)|[Dzogchen](tm.mon.7)|||,[Nyima Drakpa](tm.fig.44)|[Shechen](tm.mon.15)|||,[Nyima Drakpa](tm.fig.44)|[Samye](tm.mon.20)|||,[Nyima Drakpa](tm.fig.44)|[Lhundrubteng](tm.mon.65)|||,[Nyima Drakpa](tm.fig.44)|[Pelri Osel Tekchenling](tm.mon.19)|||

name: The Third Dodrubchen, Jigme Tenpai Nyima
description: Jigme Tenpai Nyima was son of Dudjom Lingpa. He taught the Bodhisattvacaryavatara and transmitted the Longchen Nyingtig. Jigme Tenpai Nyima also rebuilt and expanded the Dodrupchen monastery.
Associated Monasteries: "[The Third Dodrubchen, Jigme Tenpai Nyima](tm.fig.45)|[Dzogchen](tm.mon.7)|||","[The Third Dodrubchen, Jigme Tenpai Nyima](tm.fig.45)|[Dodrupchen](tm.mon.66)|||","[The Third Dodrubchen, Jigme Tenpai Nyima](tm.fig.45)|[Dzagyel](tm.mon.61)|||"

name: Pakmodrupa Dorje Gyalpo
description: Pakmodrupa Dorje Gyalpo was the founder of the Pakmodrupa Kagyu lineage. He studied with the great masters Sachen Kunga Nyingpo and Gampopa, learned meditative tantric practices like Lamdre and Mahamudra, and was especially skilled in meditation. Pakmodrupa also founded Densatil.
Associated Monasteries: [Pakmodrupa Dorje Gyalpo](tm.fig.46)|[Densatil](tm.mon.55)|||,[Pakmodrupa Dorje Gyalpo](tm.fig.46)|[Jang Tana](tm.mon.67)|||

name: Chokle Namgyel
description: Chokle Namgyel was one of Dolpopa’s disciples and taught the Kalachakra tantra and wrote commentaries on the Kalachakra texts
Associated Monasteries: [Chokle Namgyel](tm.fig.47)|[Jonang](tm.mon.10)|||,[Chokle Namgyel](tm.fig.47)|[Drakram](tm.mon.68)|||,[Chokle Namgyel](tm.fig.47)|[Sakya](tm.mon.13)|||,[Chokle Namgyel](tm.fig.47)|[Sekharchung](tm.mon.83)|||

name: Second Drukchen, Kunga Peljor
description: The second Drukchen incarnation Kunga Peljor was abbot of Ralung Monastery, transmitted treasure teachings and also the teachings of the Indian master Vanaratna.
Associated Monasteries: "[Second Drukchen, Kunga Peljor](tm.fig.48)|[Ralung](tm.mon.57)|||"

name: The Second Changkya, Ngawang Lobzang Choden
description: Like the other Changkya incarnations, Ngawang Lobzang Choden served as a tutor of the emperor in Beijing and an ambassador between the Qing court and the Dalai Lama. He founded the Songzhu Si monastery in Beijing.
Associated Monasteries: "[The Second Changkya, Ngawang Lobzang Choden](tm.fig.49)|[Drepung](tm.mon.5)|||","[The Second Changkya, Ngawang Lobzang Choden](tm.fig.49)|[Tashilhunpo](tm.mon.37)|||","[The Second Changkya, Ngawang Lobzang Choden](tm.fig.49)|[Kumbum Jampa Ling](tm.mon.28)|||","[The Second Changkya, Ngawang Lobzang Choden](tm.fig.49)|[Labrang Tashikhyil](tm.mon.69)|||","[The Second Changkya, Ngawang Lobzang Choden](tm.fig.49)|[Gonlung Jampa Ling](tm.mon.42)|||"

name: Yonten Gyatso
description: Yonten Gyatso was primarily educated in medicine. Many of students were also leaders in Tibetan medicine.
Associated Monasteries: [Yonten Gyatso](tm.fig.50)|[Sakya](tm.mon.13)|||,[Yonten Gyatso](tm.fig.50)|[Dar Drongmoche](tm.mon.121)|||

name: Pema Rangdol
description: Pema Rangdol was an expert in tantric teachings, including the Wishing Vase, Eight Sadhana Teachings, Hundred Supreme Deities , and Sadhana of the Lineage of Awareness-Holders
Associated Monasteries: [Pema Rangdol](tm.fig.51)|[Mindroling](tm.mon.39)|||,[Pema Rangdol](tm.fig.51)|[Dorje Drak](tm.mon.4)|||,[Pema Rangdol](tm.fig.51)|[Tashilhunpo](tm.mon.37)|||,[Pema Rangdol](tm.fig.51)|[Samye](tm.mon.20)|||,[Pema Rangdol](tm.fig.51)|[Amdo Chubzang](tm.mon.71)|||

name: The Eighth Ganden Tripa, Monlam Pelwa
description: Monlam Pelwa was a disciple of Gendun Drup. He served as abbot of Garden Shartse, throne holder of Ganden, and abbot of Drepung. He wrote a number of commentaries including a notable commentary on Dharmakirti’s theory of valid cognition.
Associated Monasteries: "[The Eighth Ganden Tripa, Monlam Pelwa](tm.fig.52)|[Ganden](tm.mon.8)|||","[The Eighth Ganden Tripa, Monlam Pelwa](tm.fig.52)|[Drepung](tm.mon.5)|||","[The Eighth Ganden Tripa, Monlam Pelwa](tm.fig.52)|[Tashilhunpo](tm.mon.37)|||"

name: Dudul Dorje
description: Dudul Dorje was a treasure revealer and master of Dzogchen teachings. He was especially associated with Katok monastery and traveled around Tibet revealing treasure texts. Dudul Dorje was established at Derge, his home region, for a time but fell out with the kings of Derge and the Fifth Dalai Lama, who were allies. (The Fifth Dalai Lama considered Dudul Dorje to be a fraud, and Dudul Dorje's treasure revelations contain a prophecy by Sambhava that he would be faced with slander.) Dudul Dorje then received the patronage of the rulers of Ling. He is believed to be a prior incarnation of Dudjom Rinpoche by his followers.
Associated Monasteries: [Dudul Dorje](tm.fig.53)|[Katok](tm.mon.32)|||,[Dudul Dorje](tm.fig.53)|[Pelyul](tm.mon.52)|||,[Dudul Dorje](tm.fig.53)|[Ngor](tm.mon.23)|||,[Dudul Dorje](tm.fig.53)|[Samye](tm.mon.20)|||,[Dudul Dorje](tm.fig.53)|[Lhundrubteng](tm.mon.65)|||,[Dudul Dorje](tm.fig.53)|[Bangri Jokpo](tm.mon.72)|||,[Dudul Dorje](tm.fig.53)|[Sakya](tm.mon.13)|||,[Dudul Dorje](tm.fig.53)|[Lhasa Tsuklakhang](tm.mon.94)|||,[Dudul Dorje](tm.fig.53)|[Muksang](tm.mon.96)|||

name: The Fourth Shechen Gyaltsab, Pema Namgyel
description: Pema Namgyel was an incarnate lama whose seat was Shechen. He wrote many texts on tantric practice and scholarly commentaries for students, including one on the works of Mipham.
Associated Monasteries: "[The Fourth Shechen Gyaltsab, Pema Namgyel](tm.fig.54)|[Shechen](tm.mon.15)|||"

name: The Ninth Situ, Pema Nyinje Wangpo
description: Pema Ninje Wangpo was an incarnate lama connected with the Rime nonsectarian tradition of taking teachings from different Tibetan traditions. He revived the monastic discipline of Pelpung monastery. Pema Nyinje Wangpo taught such figures as the Fourteenth Karmapa and Jamgon Kongtrul.
Associated Monasteries: "[The Ninth Situ, Pema Nyinje Wangpo](tm.fig.55)|[Karma Gon](tm.mon.36)|||","[The Ninth Situ, Pema Nyinje Wangpo](tm.fig.55)|[Pelpung](tm.mon.73)|||"

name: Sabzang Mati Panchen Lodro Gyeltsen
description: Sabzang Mati Panchen Lodro Gyeltsen was a disciple of Dolpopa who translated the Kalachakra Tantra and its commentary, the Vimalaprabha, into Tibetan.
Associated Monasteries: [Sabzang Mati Panchen Lodro Gyeltsen](tm.fig.56)|[Zhalu](tm.mon.54)|||,[Sabzang Mati Panchen Lodro Gyeltsen](tm.fig.56)|[Ralung](tm.mon.57)|||,[Sabzang Mati Panchen Lodro Gyeltsen](tm.fig.56)|[Jonang](tm.mon.10)|||,[Sabzang Mati Panchen Lodro Gyeltsen](tm.fig.56)|[Nyetang Drolma Lhakang](tm.mon.46)|||,[Sabzang Mati Panchen Lodro Gyeltsen](tm.fig.56)|[Sabzang Ganden](tm.mon.74)|||,[Sabzang Mati Panchen Lodro Gyeltsen](tm.fig.56)|[Sakya](tm.mon.13)|||

name: The First Purchok, Ngawang Jampa
description: Ngawang Jampa helped to develop the hermitage of Purchok as a center of Geluk pilgrimage. He taught Lamrim (stages of the path), the Geluk version of Mahamudra, Guhyasamaja, and many commentaries on tantric and ritual subjects that became part of the Geluk curriculum.
Associated Monasteries: "[The First Purchok, Ngawang Jampa](tm.fig.57)|[Chamdo Jampa Ling](tm.mon.75)|||","[The First Purchok, Ngawang Jampa](tm.fig.57)|[Purbuchok](tm.mon.63)|||"

name: Khyenrab Wangchuk Drakpa Zangpo
description: Khyenrab Wangchuk Drakpa Zangpo was a disciple of Tsongkhapa and Gyeltsabje who was especially learned in Madhyamaka philosophy. He taught subjects like the classics of Indian Buddhism, Vinaya, and Lamrim (Stages of the Path). The dates provided are an approximation (the sources say “late 14th cent - mid 15th cent”).
Associated Monasteries: [Khyenrab Wangchuk Drakpa Zangpo ](tm.fig.58)|[Zhalu](tm.mon.54)|||,[Khyenrab Wangchuk Drakpa Zangpo ](tm.fig.58)|[Ganden](tm.mon.8)|||,[Khyenrab Wangchuk Drakpa Zangpo ](tm.fig.58)|[Nartang](tm.mon.44)|||,[Khyenrab Wangchuk Drakpa Zangpo ](tm.fig.58)|[Sangpu](tm.mon.11)|||,[Khyenrab Wangchuk Drakpa Zangpo ](tm.fig.58)|[Nenying](tm.mon.76)|||,[Khyenrab Wangchuk Drakpa Zangpo ](tm.fig.58)|[Rato](tm.mon.87)|||,[Khyenrab Wangchuk Drakpa Zangpo ](tm.fig.58)|[Taktse Rinchen Gang](tm.mon.89)|||,[Khyenrab Wangchuk Drakpa Zangpo ](tm.fig.58)|[Sakya](tm.mon.13)|||,[Khyenrab Wangchuk Drakpa Zangpo ](tm.fig.58)|[Bodong E](tm.mon.62)|||

name: The Fourth Dorje Drak Rigdzin, Pema Trinle
description: Pema Trinle was closely associated with the Fifth Dalai Lama and his Nyingma teachers. He served as a ritual priest for the Dalai Lama, who also patronized his works on Nyingma tantric ritual. Pema Trinle greatly expanded Dorje Drak monastery. He died during the Dzungar invasion of Tibet in 1717.
Associated Monasteries: "[The Fourth Dorje Drak Rigdzin, Pema Trinle](tm.fig.59)|[Dorje Drak](tm.mon.4)|||","[The Fourth Dorje Drak Rigdzin, Pema Trinle](tm.fig.59)|[Monkhar Namseling](tm.mon.77)|||","[The Fourth Dorje Drak Rigdzin, Pema Trinle](tm.fig.59)|[Drak Yongdzong](tm.mon.90)|||"

name: The Second Dzongsar Khyentse, Jamyang Khyenste Chokyi Lodro
description: Jamyang Khyentse Chokyi Lodro was recognized as an “activity incarnation” of Jamyang Khyenste Wangpo. In the Rime (nonsectarian) tradition, he took teachings from many different traditions, and also transmitted them. He established Khamshe monastery. In the 1950s Jamyang Khyentse prophesied that there would be destruction in Kham due to Communist invasion and resistance, and also that the Buddhist tradition would survive. He went into exile in Sikkim.
Associated Monasteries: "[The Second Dzongsar Khyentse, Jamyang Khyenste Chokyi Lodro](tm.fig.60)|[Katok](tm.mon.32)|||","[The Second Dzongsar Khyentse, Jamyang Khyenste Chokyi Lodro](tm.fig.60)|[Shechen](tm.mon.15)|||","[The Second Dzongsar Khyentse, Jamyang Khyenste Chokyi Lodro](tm.fig.60)|[Ngor](tm.mon.23)|||","[The Second Dzongsar Khyentse, Jamyang Khyenste Chokyi Lodro](tm.fig.60)|[Adzom Gar](tm.mon.78)|||","[The Second Dzongsar Khyentse, Jamyang Khyenste Chokyi Lodro](tm.fig.60)|[Dzongsar](tm.mon.30)|||","[The Second Dzongsar Khyentse, Jamyang Khyenste Chokyi Lodro](tm.fig.60)|[Lhundrubteng](tm.mon.65)|||","[The Second Dzongsar Khyentse, Jamyang Khyenste Chokyi Lodro](tm.fig.60)|[Pelpung](tm.mon.73)|||"

name: Jikten Gonpo Rinchen Pel
description: Jikten Gonpo Rinchen Pel was a disciple of Pakmodrupa, for a time abbot of Densatil, and then the founder of the monastery of Drigung which became the basis of the Drigung Kagyu school. His lineage teaches the Five Profound Paths of Mahamudra.
Associated Monasteries: [Jikten Gonpo Rinchen Pel](tm.fig.61)|[Densatil](tm.mon.55)|||,[Jikten Gonpo Rinchen Pel](tm.fig.61)|[Drigung](tm.mon.6)|||,[Jikten Gonpo Rinchen Pel](tm.fig.61)|[Kailash](tm.mon.79)|||

name: Nyawon Kunga Pel
description: Nyawon Kunga Pel was a disciple of Dolopopa and a throne holder of Jonang monastery. He founded the monastery of Tsechen and taught epistemology and the Vimalaprabha commentary on the Kalachakra
Associated Monasteries: [Nyawon Kunga Pel](tm.fig.62)|[Nyetang Drolma Lhakang](tm.mon.46)|||,[Nyawon Kunga Pel](tm.fig.62)|[Tsechen](tm.mon.80)|||

name: Tsangnyon Heruka
description: Tsangnyon Heruka is the author of the famous and much-translated biography of Milarepa. He renovated the stupa of Swayambhu in Kathmandu. He displayed unconventional behavior in the “mad yogi” or siddha tradition, and spent much of his life as an itinerant meditator.

name: The First Jamyang Zhepa, Jamyang Zhepai Dorje
description: Jamyang Zhepai Dorje was a geshe from Drepung Gomang and Lower Tantric College renowned for his scholarship. He wrote the textbooks used at Drepung and Labrang, outlining the orthodox philosophical and doctrinal stances of these monasteries. One of these is the Great Exposition of Tenets. Jamyang Zhepai Dorje also wrote many other philosophical works.

name: Tukje Tsondru
description: Tukje Tsondru was a practitioner of Kalachakra who founded Jonang monastery. He also wrote commentaries on the Kalachakra Tantra.

name: Changlung Pelchen Namkha Jigme
description: Changlung Pelchen Namkha Jigme was a tantric practitioner, who was central to the establishment of tantric communities in Rebkong practicing Drupchen. He also transmitted many Nyingma tantric ceremonies.

name: Jamyang Choje Tashi Pelden
description: Jamyang Choje Tashi Pelden was the first abbot of Drepung, appointed by Tsongkhapa. He also wrote the Secret Biography of Tsongkhapa.

name: Namcho Mingyur Dorje
description: Namcho Mingyur Dorje was a treasure revealer who generally attained his revelations via personal visions. He is best known for the Namcho cycle. Namcho Mingyur Dorje founded the Pelyul branch of the Nyingma school, and consecrated many sacred sites in the Chamdo region and elsewhere in Kham.

name: Dilgo Khyentse Tashi Peljor
description: Dilgo Khyentse Tashi Peljor was born into a family of prominent Nyingma practitioners and patrons of Jamyang Khyentse Wangpo. He was considered by some as a tulku of Jamyang Khyentse Wangpo. He took novice ordination but then lived the life of a lay tantrika with a wife and children. Dilgo Khyentse was a prolific reveler of treasure texts. In 1956 he fled to Lhasa after the People’s Liberation Army seized control and he escaped to Tibet after the departure of the Dalai Lama in 1959 and settled in Bhutan. Dilgo Khyentse began teaching Westerners in the 1970s. His seat was Shechen and he reestablished the monastery in Boudhanath, Nepal in 1980. He was able to return to Tibet in the 1980s and consecrated rebuilt temples such as Samye.
